author: Mark Frary
title: Flybe put my grandchild at risk
text:
Many airlines offer a service that allows children to travel without their parents. They’re watched over during the journey and handed over to a named adult on the other side of security. With heightened fears over child abduction, such services should offer peace of mind. Unfortunately, as reader Norma Lawrie found out, mistakes can be made that put children at risk.
On August 1, Norma’s 11-year-old grand-daughter was returning home from Glasgow on a Flybe flight as an unaccompanied minor. This service is offered for children aged between 5 and 12.
Anyone using this service on Flybe has to provide details of the person taking the child to the airport and the person collecting at the other end. The person collecting has to show ID. The airline charges a supervisory fee of £39 per child per flight.
